Submodules¶

pyproct.clustering.metrics.CalinskiHarabasz module¶

Created on 11/06/2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.CalinskiHarabasz.CalinskiHarabaszCalculator[source]¶

Bases: object

Implementation of the Calinski-Harabasz (VRC) index, as described in T. Calinski and J.Harabasz paper in ‘Communications in Statistics 3(1), 1-27 (1974)’. Contains the necessary functions to calculate the index in the two forms presented.

classmethod A_k(clustering, D, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the A_k term. @param clustering: The clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The A_k term value.

classmethod BGSS(clustering, D, matrix)[source]¶

C-H description of the “Between group sum of squares”. @param clustering: The clustering being checked. @param D: Mean distance of the sum of all squared distances present in the matrix. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The value of BGSS.

classmethod WGSS(clusters, matrix)[source]¶

C-H description of the “Within group sum of squares”. @param clusters: An array with all clusters description (usually Clustering.clusters) @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The value of WGSS.

classmethod ch_cluster_term(cluster, global_mean_distance, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates one of the formula terms (ng-1)(D-d_g) @param cluster: The cluster to use in calculation. @param global_mean_distance: ‘D’. Is the mean of the n*(n-1)/2 distances of all the elements. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: Calculated term.

evaluate(clustering, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the index value for a clustering. @param clustering: The clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The calculated Calinski-Harabasz (VRC) index.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.CalinskiHarabasz.mean(array)[source]¶

pyproct.clustering.metrics.DaviesBouldin module¶

Created on May 30, 2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.DaviesBouldin.DaviesBouldinCalculator[source]¶

Bases: object

Is an estimator of cluster validity. The lower the better.

classmethod calc_average_distances(clustering, matrix)[source]¶
classmethod calculate_average_distance_from_prototype(cluster, matrix)[source]¶

Returns the average distance of the elements of a cluster with its medoid. @param cluster: The cluster from which we want to calculate this distance. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The calculated value.

classmethod d_b_term_calculation(i, j, d, clusters, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates one of the terms as defined in the paper (di+dj) / d(ci,cj) @param i: Is the index of the first cluster (in ‘clusters’) to calculate the term. @param j: The index of the second cluster. @param clusters: An array containing all the clusters of the clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The value of the term.

classmethod db_index_calculation(d, clusters, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the summation of the terms for all clusters vs all the other clusters of the clustering. @param d: Array containing the mean distances to the centroid (medoid) for all clusters (with index correspondence). @param clusters: An array containing all the clusters of the clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The index value.

classmethod db_terms_for_cluster(i, d, clusters, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the summation of the terms for a cluster vs all the other clusters of the clustering. @param i: Is the index of the first cluster (in ‘clusters’) to calculate the term. @param d: Array containing the mean distances to the centroid (medoid) for all clusters (with index correspondence). @param clusters: An array containing all the clusters of the clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The value for each term (i vs j[0..n] j!=i).

evaluate(clustering, matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the index value for a clustering. @param clustering: The clustering being checked. @param matrix: The condensed matrix containing all distances. @return: The calculated Davies-Bouldin estimator value.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.boundedCohesion module¶

Created on 09/01/2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.boundedCohesion.MirrorCohesionCalculator[source]¶

Bases: object

Bounded in [0,1] where 0 means the perfect cohesion and 1 the worst. Doesn’t use the prototype.

evaluate(clustering, condensed_distance_matrix)[source]¶

Returns the cohesion value of a cluster. The weight will be the number of elements of each cluster.

The maximum value will be (in the case we have only one cluster) the sum of all the pair distances. We can avoid the 2x factor, increasing the performance.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.cohesion module¶

Created on 09/01/2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.cohesion.CohesionCalculator[source]¶

Bases: object

evaluate(clustering, matrix)[source]¶
evaluate_cluster(cluster, condensed_distance_matrix)[source]¶

Returns the cohesion value of a cluster. The condensed matrix given as parameter stores the distances of the elements of the dataset used to extract the cluster.

The definition of cohesion would be weight*2*cohesion in the case we follow the exact formula in the book []. As we are going to do comparisons, the x2 global multiplication doesn’t affect.

Cohesion of a cluster of 1 element should be infinite instead of 0...

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics module¶

Created on 13/08/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.MinMaxCut[source]¶

Bases: object

Within cluster similarity.

evaluate(clustering, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Evaluates: MinMaxCut = sum_{i=1}^k cut(A_i,A_i-complementary) / W(A_i,A_i)

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.NCut[source]¶

Bases: object

Is a very simple separation measure.

evaluate(clustering, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Evaluates: NCut = 1/2 sum_{i=1}^k W(A_i,A_i-complementary) / vol(A_i)

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.RatioCut[source]¶

Bases: object

Is another simple separation measure.

evaluate(clustering, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Evaluates: RatioCut = sum_{i=1}^k cut(A_i,A_i-complementary) / card(A_i)

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.W(A1, A2, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

W(A,B) = sum_{i pert A, j pert B} w_i_j

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.all_cut(clustering, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Cut measure of the connected component A vs the complementary set.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.d(i, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Degree of a vertex: d_i = sum_{j=1}^n w_ij

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.getClusterAndComplementary(i, all_clusters)[source]¶

Returns the list representing the elements of cluster ‘ith’ and the list representing the sum of elements of all other clusters.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.single_cut(A, Acomp, condensed_matrix)[source]¶
pyproct.clustering.metrics.graphMetrics.vol(A, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

vol(A) = sum_{i pert A} d_i

pyproct.clustering.metrics.meanMinimumDistance module¶

Created on 09/01/2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.meanMinimumDistance.MeanMinimumDistanceCalculator(seed_num=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

evaluate(clustering, condensed_matrix, subsampling_percent=20)[source]¶
get_distances_less_than_mean(distances, mean)[source]¶

Returns an array with distances wich are smaller than the given mean.

get_mean_and_min_distances(cluster1, cluster2, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Returns the minimum distances for the elements of cluster1 vs cluster2.

subsample(cluster_size, subsampling_percent, distances)[source]¶

It chooses a percent of random given distances and calculates the mean.

subsampled_mean_min_dist(cluster1, cluster2, subsampling_percent, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Does the calculation for two clusters. This implies that for each pair of clusters it gets the min_dists and those of min_dists that are smaller than the mean to get the subsampled value.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.meanMinimumDistance.mean_function(my_list)[source]¶

Function wrapper to handle difficult cases (like empty lists :/ ).

pyproct.clustering.metrics.pcaMetrics module¶

Created on 13/08/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.pcaMetrics.PCAMetric(trajectory_handler)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is a metric based in the PCA of the clusters composing a clustering,

classmethod calculate_biggest_eigenvalue(covariance_matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of a covariance matrix.

@param covariance_matrix: The covariance matrix.

@return: The first (bigger) eigenvalue, which gives an idea of the relative importance of the axis responsible of most of the variance.

classmethod create_covariance_matrix(coordinates)[source]¶

Calculates the covariance matrix for a given number of conformations

@param coordinates: Coordinates of the trajectory frames we want to use in the covariance matrix calculation. This coordinates are stored in the format [conformation 1..N] where conformation is [Atom 1...N] Where atom is [x,y,z], so it’s a (C,A,3) shaped matrix where C is the number of conformations and N the number of atoms per conformation.

@return: The covariance matrix.

evaluate(clustering)[source]¶

Calculates the value of the PCA metric, which is the mean of the largest eigenvalue obtained from the PCA (the one corresponding to the axis of bigger variability) weighted by the cluster size.

@param clustering: The clustering we want to calculate the metric.

@return: the value of the metric.

pyproct.clustering.metrics.silhouette module¶

Created on 02/05/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.metrics.silhouette.SilhouetteCoefficientCalculator[source]¶

Bases: object

Between -1 and 1. 1 Is the value for the better clustering (best separated and with best cohesion. 0 can be a not-so-good-and-not-so-bad clustering, but a random clustering would get results around this.

evaluate(clustering, condensed_distance_matrix, element=None, cluster=None)[source]¶

Evaluates the silhouette factor for 3 types of elements in the clusterization hierarchy: - element silhouette: it needs to define the element and the cluster to which this element belongs - cluster: only needs to define the cluster. - clusterization: calculates the silhouette factor of a whole clusterization.
